**Theodor Herzl's Legacy**

Herzl's ideas and activism laid the foundation for the modern State of Israel. Theodor Herzl, born to Hungarian Jewish parents in **Budapest** on **May 2**, **1860**, was a multi-talented intellectual who lived through many historical epochs that shaped the course of Jewish life. Growing up in a wealthy, assimilated family, Herzl was exposed to German literature and culture, and this informed his worldview.

As a **teenager**, Herzl discovered the **New Ghetto**, a play that dealt with the social life of upper-class Jews in **Vienna**. He went on to study law at **the University of Vienna**, where he joined a liberal intellectual circle and made connections.

Herzl initially focused on writing **novels**, _Altneuland_ (1902–1904) being his masterpiece. He moved to **Zurich** in 1896 to join his wife, but in **1897**, following the failure of a socialist workers' association he had co-founded, he became a journalist at the _Neue Freie Presse_ in **Vienna**.

In 1898 Herzl received the prestigious **Förderpreis** (award) for his journalistic writing. His first feuilleton, "A Jew in Austria," was published in **August** 1899.

In **1902**, Herzl moved to New York City, working as a journalist for the **New York Staats-Zeitung**. He returned to Vienna in **1903** and published _Der Judenstaat_ (The State of the Jews), which brought him international recognition and was widely discussed. The book advocates for the creation of a **Jewish homeland** in Palestine.

In addition to his literary works, Herzl was deeply involved in **politics**, serving as the chairman of the ** Austrian Zionist Organization** from 1908 to 1913 and founding the **Central Organization for Jewish Labor in Austria**.

In **1919**, Herzl died of a **rheumatoid arthritis attack** in **Paris**. _Der Judenstaat_ became a blueprint for the **establishment** of the modern state of Israel, which was founded in 1948.
